instruction: Wash the seeraga samba rice under running water 2–3 times until the water runs clear.
title: Rinse the Rice

transcript_segments.text: Greetings from Mulakkam Welcome to Tooty’s Kitchen Chennai. Today we’re going to see a very, very famous Dindigul-style Thalappakatti Mutton Biryani. We’ll make it just like how it’s served at the restaurant—guaranteed to get that authentic taste.

instruction: Soak the washed rice in water for 20–30 minutes. This helps it cook evenly and absorb flavors better.
title: Soak the Rice

transcript_segments.text: Now we’re going to grind a special masala. For that, take 100g of shallots. Shallots are a must for this. Then take 50g of garlic and 50g of ginger. Also, take some green chilies depending on your spice level.

instruction: In a bowl, mix curd, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, black pepper powder, and salt.
title: Prepare Marinade

transcript_segments.text: Add 8 cloves, 8 cardamoms, just 1 star anise, a small piece of mace, and a small piece of nutmeg. If you have nutmeg powder, that’s fine too. Just use a little bit.

Now grind everything into a fine powder. No need to dry roast anything—just grind directly. For the mutton, we’ve taken 700g. For half a kilo of rice, use about half a kilo of mutton. You can use a bit more if you like.

instruction: Add the mutton or chicken to the marinade and coat well. Let it rest for 30 minutes to 1 hour.
title: Marinate the Meat

transcript_segments.text: Add enough water for the mutton to cook. Then add 2 teaspoons of salt. Mix everything well, pressure cook it for about 4-5 whistles until the mutton is nicely cooked. While that’s cooking, we’ll grind the masala.

instruction: In a heavy-bottomed pot, heat the oil and optional ghee over medium heat.
title: Heat the Oil and Ghee

transcript_segments.text: When grinding, don’t add too much water. Just a little is enough to make a coarse paste—not too fine. It should look like this. Now let’s grind the garam masala as well. The aroma is so good even while grinding.
Now both our pastes are ready. Once you grind these two pastes, the biryani becomes very easy to prepare. Let’s get started. Heat 3 tablespoons of ghee in a kadai (pan).
Let it heat well for a few minutes. Now add the ground garam masala paste. Sauté this well for a few minutes too.

instruction: Add fennel seeds, cloves, cardamom, cinnamon, bay leaf, and star anise. Fry until aromatic (about 30 seconds).
title: Fry Whole Spices

transcript_segments.text: Let it heat well for a few minutes. Now add the ground garam masala paste. Sauté this well for a few minutes too.

instruction: Add the sliced onions and cook until they turn golden brown, stirring occasionally.
title: Sauté the Onions

transcript_segments.text: Let it heat well for a few minutes. Now add the ground garam masala paste. Sauté this well for a few minutes too.

instruction: Stir in the ginger-garlic paste and slit green chilies. Cook until the raw smell disappears (around 2–3 minutes).
title: Add Ginger-Garlic Paste and Chilies

transcript_segments.text: Let it heat well for a few minutes. Now add the ground garam masala paste. Sauté this well for a few minutes too.

instruction: Add the chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften and oil begins to separate from the mixture.
title: Cook the Tomatoes

transcript_segments.text: Let it heat well for a few minutes. Now add the ground garam masala paste. Sauté this well for a few minutes too.

instruction: Mix in mint leaves and coriander leaves. Cook for another 1–2 minutes until wilted and fragrant.
title: Add Fresh Herbs

transcript_segments.text: Let it heat well for a few minutes. Now add the ground garam masala paste. Sauté this well for a few minutes too.

instruction: Transfer the marinated meat into the pot. Stir well to combine with the masala base.
title: Add Marinated Meat

transcript_segments.text: Let it heat well for a few minutes. Now add the ground garam masala paste. Sauté this well for a few minutes too.

instruction: Cook the meat on medium heat until it's partially cooked and the masala is thick and clings to the meat.
title: Cook the Meat

transcript_segments.text: Now let’s check if the mutton is cooked. Yes, it’s cooked well. Drain the water and add just the mutton to the masala now.

instruction: Add 3 1/2 cups of water to the pot. Stir and bring it to a boil over high heat.
title: Pour Water

transcript_segments.text: Now let’s check if the mutton is cooked. Yes, it’s cooked well. Drain the water and add just the mutton to the masala now.

instruction: Taste and adjust salt as needed. The water should taste slightly salty at this stage.
title: Season the Water

transcript_segments.text: Now let’s check if the mutton is cooked. Yes, it’s cooked well. Drain the water and add just the mutton to the masala now.

instruction: Reduce the heat and simmer the meat for 5–10 minutes until it becomes tender.
title: Simmer the Meat

transcript_segments.text: Now roast the mutton in the oil for a few minutes until it slightly changes color. Then add chopped mint and coriander leaves. Roast this together for a few minutes as well.
Once the mutton is well roasted, add the masala powders: 1 tbsp chili powder, 1 tbsp coriander powder, and ½ tbsp cumin powder. Sauté until the raw smell goes away.
Once it reaches this stage and oil starts to separate, add 100g of curd.

instruction: Drain the soaked rice completely and gently add it to the pot with the meat and broth.
title: Drain and Add Rice

transcript_segments.text: Now it looks perfect. At this stage, squeeze in the juice of one lemon. For cooking the rice, measure 2 cups of water for every 1 cup of rice. I’ve used part of the water from the mutton broth and the rest as fresh water.

instruction: Stir the rice gently into the liquid, taking care not to break the grains.
title: Mix Gently

transcript_segments.text: Now it looks perfect. At this stage, squeeze in the juice of one lemon. For cooking the rice, measure 2 cups of water for every 1 cup of rice. I’ve used part of the water from the mutton broth and the rest as fresh water.

Personally, I feel seeraga samba rice works better than basmati for this. It cooks faster too. So always use the 1:2 rice-to-water ratio. If not, the rice won’t cook uniformly and might remain a bit hard.

instruction: Cover the pot with a tight-fitting lid. Cook on low heat for 15–20 minutes until the rice is fully cooked and the water is absorbed.
title: Cook on Dum

transcript_segments.text: Mix everything well. Once the water boils, add the soaked seeraga samba rice. Mix again and cover. Let it cook on medium flame for about 10 minutes.
After 10 minutes, open it up. The rice should be almost cooked at this stage. Now add 1 tablespoon of ghee on top.
Now close the lid and place a dosa tawa under the pan. Let it go on "dum" for 15 minutes—first 5 minutes on high flame, and the remaining 10 minutes on low flame.

instruction: Turn off the heat and let the biryani rest, covered, for 10 minutes to allow flavors to settle.
title: Rest the Biryani

transcript_segments.text: After 15 minutes, it will look like this. Gently mix it once and then close it again. Turn off the heat and let it rest, covered, for another 10 minutes before opening.
Now after 10-15 minutes, we’ll open it. Look at that! The rice is perfectly cooked and fluffy. Our aromatic Thalappakatti-style Mutton Biryani is ready!

instruction: Drizzle lemon juice over the cooked biryani. Gently fluff the rice to mix without breaking it.
title: Add Lemon Juice
